results.title: Working together: agriculture
results.brief_description: The story of co-operative farming in Sweden. In the 1930s farmers faced the threat of eviction from the land - only with difficulty could they sell the products from their soil. Today, through voluntary co-operatives, modern farming methods have been adopted bringing greater efficiency and prosperity to the industry. Illustrates co-operatives at work in the dairy, meat what, timber and poultry industries and in providing finance or home building, community centres, libraries and study circles.

results.title: Working together in the classroom; Supporting understanding
results.brief_description: Language in the multi-ethnic classroom; parts 2 & 3. Part 2. “Working together” in the classroom. The main focus of this program is to develop and enhance the speaking skills of primary school children. Part 3. “Supporting understanding.” Suggest that children learn by doing, therefore, teachers need to create situations which will allow children to use and extend the language they learn. In both of these programs we see activities which will help to develop and reinforce language, showing teachers using the activities in actual classroom situations. Companion videotape “Listen to us; The way we speak.”

results.title: Working together
results.brief_description: Describes employment opportunities for handicapped people in the Great Yarmouth area. Focuses on the possibilities raised by extensive co-operation between the local Disablement Resettlement Officer, the Adult Training Centre and one enlightened employer.

results.title: Working together
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle and Australian Dairy Board
results.brief_description: South-East Asia is rich in natural resources and food potential is good but an improvement in farming techniques is needed and high protein foods are scarce. Australia, with its highly mechanised dairy industry, can provide aid and personnel in setting up and maintaining jointly-owned factories is such countries as Indonesia, Hong Kong, Singapore, the Philippines and Japan.

results.title: Working on it
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training and Film Australia
results.brief_description: An extensive cross section of people relate their experiences of termination and unemployment. Participants provide ideas to assist viewers in obtaining employment including the role of the CES, regularly scanning newspapers, networking with colleagues/mates and especially emphasising the importance of word-of-mouth. Addresses depression vs. motivation, preparation of an up-to-date resume, the importance of pre-interview research and interview tips, particularly selling yourself. Stresses not to give up despite the discouragement of rejection and maintain confidence by adopting a positive and open attitude towards re-education or career direction changes.

results.title: Working in a store
results.creator_credit: Kay Mander, Sir Arthur Hallam Elton and Basic Films
results.brief_description: The second film in the series “Is this the job for me?” shows what it is like to work in a stores as seen through the eyes of a young girl who has just left school. It gives an unvarnished account of the life of a salesgirl; points out the advantages and disadvantages of this type of work and describes the opportunities for advancement.

results.title: Working elephants of Siam
results.brief_description: Provides a study of the teak industry in the tropical uplands of Thailand. Shows elephants hauling and lifting the teak logs in the forests and swimming in the river in the evening.

results.title: Workcover: a comprehensive video guide
results.creator_credit: Steven King, Dieter Vornhagen, Kingwest Productions and Video Master
results.brief_description: Andrew Ellis, solicitor, discusses the individual’s rights to compensation for work related injuries. Topics include: the role of the solicitor; making a claim for compensation; lump sums for permanent disability; the role of the courts and dispute settlement. This program is intended as a starting point, not as a replacement for expert legal advice.

results.title: Work study: work measurement, basic principles
results.creator_credit: Anvil Films and British Productivity Council
results.brief_description: An examination of time study, as a work measurement technique. The importance of rating and the less direct methods of deriving standard times - analysis and synthesis (including Predetermined Motion Time Standards) are considered. Shows a manufacturer faced with the problem of a particularly large order.

results.title: Work study: its application to teamwork
results.brief_description: How the analytical techniques of Work Study can be used to improve operations carried out by more than one person. Emphasises the need for good communications and for having the men concerned take part in groups discussions where criticism and suggestions can be fully voiced. Shows the original conditions in a galvanising shop, the identification of improvement needed and how they were adopted co-operatively. Touches on problems of redundancy.
